topics.body:
"@ToskiHero":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/552559ce6368725a006b2c00#post_552559ce6368725a006b2c00
The thing is though that ultra-realistic robots and such aren't a cost effective goal.

What I mean by this is let's say you want to invent a humanoid robot to be a waiter or such, a problem in Japan is that the elderly are rejecting non-humanoid robotic care-takers but on the flipside too realistic will be rejected as well, anyways my point is that in order for humanoid robots to be successful they have to be less than $10k so as to undersell human workers and they can't be too realistic or too unrealistic.  What I'm thinking of is more along the lines of a animatronic robot that has clothes covering most of it's body to hide itself from people judging it too hard and that say it's face would have to be idealized rather than realistic and essentially use motion capture on how the person is talking rather than willy nilly moving it's face and mouth.

Tl:dr; make humanoid robots cute rather than realistic.
